title: Rona Fairhead and Sajid Javid appear before MPs â as it happened | Media | The Guardian
summary: liddiment : `` will be no backdoor deal around bbc3 . ''
javid hints that he believes the royal charter should not be scrapped .
javid concerned about impact on indies of bbc proposal to spin-off production business .
javid says `` fresh look '' needed at how the bbc should be governed .
javid : ruling nothing out in bbc funding options .
terms of reference for government 's tv licence review published .

documents.title: summary
text: new bbc trust chairman rhona fairhead , trustee david liddiment , director jon zeff and culture secretary sajid javid appeared before mps on the culture , media and sport committee to be grilled on the future of the bbc .

javid says he is ruling nothing out looking at future funding options for the bbc fairhead says controversial plan to move bbc3 online only in and of itself good new bbc trust chair denies going native after just two weeks in the role javid says a fresh look at bbc governance model is needed david liddiment admits fault line in bbc trust and public view is it is not fit for purpose javid indicates bbc will remain under a royal charter , other options risk threat to independence
and that concludes the final session of the house of commons culture , media and sport select committee 's look at the future of the bbc .

documents.title: javid hints that he believes the royal charter should not be scrapped
text: javid indicates that he sees no reason to meddle with the bbc 's royal charter , that looking to govern the corporation through any other mechanism poses big risks .
the current structure of the royal charter is still relevant today , he said .
anything that has big impact on the independence of the bbc should be treated very carefully .
notwithstanding that parliament 's role is very important in holding bbc to account .

what i would absolutely expect and certainly happen if i was secretary of state at the time [ of charter review ] is once government puts forward a proposal for charter it should be debated in the house and mps given an opportunity to share their views .

documents.title: javid says `` fresh look '' needed at how the bbc should be governed
text: javid admits that there are issues around governance , particularly around accountability , and is not sure if the changes in governance made to date will prove effective .
who is ultimately responsible , who has taken the decision .
that [ issue ] was recognised by the bbc trust itself .
that initiated some changes .
other changes have also been made made , such as putting more non-executives on the board .
the question is does it respond correctly to the mistakes made in the past i 'm not sure .
i think there definitely needs to be a fresh look at what the governance structure should be in the charter review process .
some people have said should there be one board .
other ideas out there are should ofcom have a role .
another idea i 've heard about is should there be a bbc trust-type structure but independent from the bbc , for example not funded by the bbc .
these are good questions .
i do n't have an answer at this point .

documents.title: javid concerned about impact on indies of bbc proposal to spin-off production business
text: conor burns asks if javid is concerned about the impact on the market of the bbc proposal to make the bbc tv production more open and competitive in the market .
javid replies : yes i would , i think given the size of the bbc in our creative media sector the amount of production it commissions it has an impact on the market .

not withstanding the bbc has its own rules on internal competition and not distorting the market , i think this issue of what kind of impact it has on market , how it might distort the market - there is an argument you could say helps market grow but people would be concerned if it is stifling creativity and competition .
john whittingdale asks about the option of full privatisation of the bbc tv production operation .
javid says : this comes back to whole issue of the size of the bbc and does it need to be doing everything does .
these are good legitimate questions .
yes , it would form part of charter review .
he adds that the same goes for spinning off bbc worldwide : that has to be part of the charter review process .
whittingdale asks what javid thinks about ripa being used to chase people over non-payment of bbc licence fee .
javid says : i think this whole issue of people who are n't paying how do you go after them and get them to pay needs to be looked at and looked at carefully .
precisely the question you ask there mr chairman is why this needs to be looked at carefully .
here is the guardian story on the review and the high-flying barrister who will lead it .
financial times telecoms correspondent daniel thomas has just tweeted : daniel thomas ( @ danielthomasldn ) sajid javid , culture sec , never misses dr who , he tells bbc select cttee .
but does n't like newsnight so much anymore # media # breakingnews
ben bradshaw goes for the classic favourite bbc tv shows question .
javid says most days it is a bbc news programme .
admits he used to be a newsnight fan , not so much anymore .
bradshaw presses .
javid says : i do n't find it as compelling viewing as i did before .
he appears to grin , then adds : i do n't know maybe it is because one of the presenters or something has left .
paxman fan ?
says only show he watches regularly is doctor who .
but he records that .
reckons he dabbles in bbc iplayer but not for doctor who .
sajid javid , secretary of state for culture , media and sport , gives evidence
he says over-75s licence fee subsidy will continue .
leaves door open as to whether that concession under general taxation could move to being paid by the bbc .
we have no such plans , others have mooted this , that is a decision for the government at the time .

documents.title: javid : ruling nothing out in bbc funding options
text: javid says funding alternatives to the licence fee will all be considered .
i 've made no decision .
what i would say at the outset is right thing during charter review process is rule out no options .
there are various models out there and charter review should rule nothing out and nothing in and take a fresh look .
he admits that he believes that â£ 145.50 a year is a lot of money for some families .
the lib dems ' john leech asks about the retransmission fees review .
that decision to have that review is not directly related to the bbc , javid says .
he adds that it was an old system designed to help the one-time struggling cable/pay-tv platforms .
it makes sense to look at them .
he points out also looking at rules governing positioning on electronic programming guide .
it makes sense to look at these rules to see if they are fit for purpose .
asked about whether â£ 3.7bn a year is too much javid says : hard to say .
javid says funding and governance needs to be looked at to make sure bbc after charter review is what everyone would agree on .
john whittingdale asks for javid 's general view of the bbc .
javid replies : like most people i admire a lot of what the bbc does .
much of it is high quality output .
it is an institution respected in many ways , not just at home .
having said that , i think it should rightly be accountable to licence fee payers , it has been very tested over last few years .
there is a bit of question mark over how accountable it has been ¦ the dmi , severance payments .
many licence fee payers concerned about whether money being well spent .
it receives â£ 3.7bn a year , that is a huge amount of money .
one thing we must all do is hold it to account .
is huge amount of money for any organisation .

javid this morning announced the appointment of david perry qc , who has worked on cases such as the abu hamza prosecution , to lead the review into whether non-payment of the licence fee should be decriminalised .
says there will not be any green or white papers before the charter review .
javid justifies the shorter time saying i have n't come across anything that suggests to me three years is required .
i felt if it starts earlier than the election it might get unnecessarily too politicised and too bogged down in day to day politics .
is not necessary to have a three year period ( like last one ) there is enough time to go through all the key issues .
i feel there is enough time .
asked why delaying charter review until after next election :
javid has this morning published the terms of reference for a review of the bbc tv licence fee , including whether non-payment should be decriminalised .
timing is everything .

documents.title: next up : sajid javid
text: and that 's it from fairhead , liddiment and zeff .
next up is culture secretary sajid javid .
over to my colleague mark sweney .

tory mp conor burns says feeling among many independent producers that bbc is not transparent over costs of production and could end up with significant market distortion with plans to open up bbc in-house production .
fairhead says tony hall 's compete or compare initiative , announced earlier this year , is one of those ideas that sounds great in principle but devil really is in the detail .
the management needs to be clear about what it is proposing , to give any sense of clarity to those independents .
she says she ca n't guarantee that all numbers [ the indies ] want will be given .
she says : the aim is good , the concerns are legitimate as to what will be the commercial impact .
liddiment says a ty plc-style board is not enough to oversee the bbc .
there should be an entity that protects the public value in the bbc , whatever that is called , bbc trust , ofbeeb , whatever , he says .
on whether that should be media regulator ofcom , says it would n't be appropriate for the bbc .
it prides itself on light touch regulation .
is too important for that .

documents.title: liddiment : `` will be no backdoor deal around bbc3 . ''
text: labour mp paul farrelly expressing mild disbelief that tony hall , having announced the closure of the bbc3 tv channel in march ( it will continue online ) , still has n't submitted a formal detailed proposal to the bbc trust .
liddiment says will be full public consultation and will publish bbc management proposal .
no one is going to do a backdoor deal around bbc3 , he says .
says proposal is imminent .
jon zeff says the trust is currently looking at radio 1 's proposed iplayer channel .
need to consider if it amounts to significant change that will trigger public value test .
on tony hall 's appointment , liddiment says his name was brought to the trust as george entwistle 's successor .
something needed to be done and done quickly , he says .
liddiment adds : i absolutely accept , under normal circumstances , a proper appointments process should be carried out .
alex spence , times media editor , has tweeted : alex spence ( @ spencetimes ) john whittingdale demands answers about bbc 's use of ripa to enforce licence fee .
he does n't get any .

documents.title: terms of reference for government 's tv licence review published
text: and here they are .
we have now moved on to the issue of bbc 's governance .

liddiment says the great tragedy of the severance row those big bbc payoffs ( think mark byford , caroline thomson ) was that it was born out of a very good piece of trust work , reducing the cost of bbc management .

documents.title: liddiment : `` fault line '' emerged in way bbc trust was set up
text: liddiment says the trust acquitted itself clearly not very well in recent years .
says the widespread view is the trust is not fit for purpose .
whether that is fair is a separate issue .
what is clear , there was a fault line in the way the trust was set up that i think we only properly came to grips with quite recently .
that was getting granular and very specific about responsibilities .
says particular issue is in relation to non-executives directors on bbc board and their role .
whittingdale says commercial broadcasters are making strong pitch that satellite broadcasters should pay for their content .
this is the retransmission fees row first brought into the public domain by former bbc dg mark thompson .
itv and channel 4 ( in its chief executive david abraham 's edinburgh lecture ) now want sky to pay up .
liddiment : something the bbc will have to think about very carefully .
fairhead does not comment .
fairhead says the bbc will be looking at generating other sources of income outside of the licence fee , but only as part of charter renewal .
it is not doing it now .
fairhead , asked about the potential decriminalisation of the licence fee : in an ideal world , people would pay if they watch , listen or use the bbc .
in an ideal world , no one would be put in prison ¦ 95 % of the population do pay , for those people they effectively subsidise those who choose the bbc and choose not to pay .
is it fair others should be subsidising what is a universal fee ?
it is entirely appropriate that all the facts are gathered in terms of what the options are [ in the government review into decrimininalisation ] .
once those facts are established , we will be in a better situation to decide is that the appropriate route to go down with civil penalties rather than criminal .
the terms of reference of the government 's review were published today , she says .
the dcms has just published the terms of reference for the review of tv licence enforcement .
it has also been annouced that the review will be independently led by david perry qc .
the statement is available here : the terms of reference have been published here :

documents.title: trust chief : licence fee works and public supports it
text: fairhead says it is her growing assumption that the licence fee works and is effective and the public broadly supports it .
in that case , asks philip davies , if the licence fee is so popular and such good value for money , why does the bbc need non-payment to be a criminal offence ?
this relates to potential decriminalisation in a review brought forward by the government .

documents.title: fairhead : bbc trust has received two letters relating to nick pollard 's savile inquiry
text: fairhead says she has received two letters in relation to the nick pollard report into the savile scandal and the subsequent newsnight crisis .
they have made assertions which we will look into , she says .
as with any decision , she says , we have to look to see is there anything material in it that would require further attention .
philip davies questions rona fairhead .
more from jane martinson at the hearing : jane martinson ( @ janemartinson ) now phillip davies says fairhead has already `` gone native '' all getting a bit cross in this hearing

documents.title: tory mp philip davies asks fairhead : `` have you gone native in record time ? ''
text: davies , warming to his theme , says he was alarmed by some of fairhead 's earlier responses .
says she appears to have gone into the job thinking the bbc is wonderful and now thinks it 's more wonderful .
asks fairhead : have you gone native in record time ?
absolutely not , says fairhead .
i do n't think i have gone native , i do n't ever intend to go native .
tory mp philip davies seizes on liddiment 's admission that many viewers do n't know about the bbc trust .
how long before they do know about it , he asks .
what matters is that audiences care deeply about the bbc , says liddiment .
ben bradshaw not happy with the trust , says it is busted and suggests it is digging itself a hole by taking on responsibility for putting forward bbc and viewers ' views during charter renewal .
you seem to want to have a death wish .

documents.title: fairhead : public regard the licence fee as the bbc 's licence fee
text: rona fairhead not keen , as you 'd expect , on further top slicing of licence fee for other ( eg commercial ) services .
fairhead says : the public regard licence fee as the bbc 's licence fee .
the benefits are clear , that there is a certain amount , an amount that can be ring fenced and you and the public can hold the trust accountable for the spending of that money .

it gives you creative freedom and that independence , it allows you to invest in longer term issues , most of the public think it is the bbc licence and there are a lot of advantages for ring fencing it on that basis .
jane martinson ( @ janemartinson ) i 'm not sure that many licence fee payers know what bbc trust is , says liddiment prompting a few raised eyebrows from committee
liddiment says many viewers wo n't know about the bbc trust , despite its role representing their interests .
but he says it does n't stop it doing its job .
we 're only eight years old , he says .
lib dem mp john leech , asking the questions , looks faintly appalled that not everyone knows about it .

documents.title: trust chief : set our funding for next 10 years
text: fairhead says funding of bbc should be set for a 10-year period in the new licence fee deal .
a sensible amount of time , she says .
it gives you some creative freedom , flexibility and ability to plan a little bit for the longer term .
five is too short ; 15 , people might feel a bit uncomfortable .
ten is about right .
one of the key areas for the bbc is its independence .
to have that length of time allows it to have that independent voice .

documents.title: fairhead on bbc3 : idea of moving it online-only `` in and of itself is good ''
text: asked about bbc3 and younger viewers , fairhead says : the idea of moving bbc3 and making it online in and of itself is good .
we have n't done our final review of bbc3 .

it 's a really difficult challenge , if you look at the statistics , it will show that group of the public are watching less , they are certainly watching very differently , although sometimes they view by appointment , ty they eat or watch on the go through devices that they have , she says .

the idea of moving bbc3 and making it online in and of itself is good , we can come back to the totality of that , but i think challenging the bbc executive and production teams to think about what works well online , because it is different , is important .
in the charter review , what i would expect is we would get the feedback from the younger audience and that will feed into what we do as a universal broadcaster .
we are there to address the needs and wants of all licence-fee payers .
liddiment says another bbc1 saturday night show , the voice , was accused of being derivative of other shows .
undoubtedly a singing talent competition , x factor , pop idol , is a singing competition .
it has its own spin , it is arguable how distinct it is from the shows .
it proved to very popular , particularly with a younger audience .
i would like to see the bbc as much as possible focused on fresh and new , original , innovative ideas preferably created from this country .
liddiment says there will inevitably be grey area where commercial tv thinks the bbc is treading on its ground with its big entertainment shows .
but says commercial tv would never have come up with big saturday night hits like strictly come dancing .
at its best ¦ adding value .
jane martinson ( @ janemartinson ) more partnerships are sensible , says fairhead .
look for tie up with ft and bbc soon ?

the guardian 's head of media , jane martinson , who is at today 's hearing , has tweeted : jane martinson ( @ janemartinson ) fairhead ducks question on what bbc should do less of by saying it 's for the public to decide where should do more and where do less
first mention of the iplayer , regarded as outstanding piece of technology , says fairhead .
that 's what the bbc can and should do .
more partnerships are sensible , she adds .
on whether the bbc should cut back on what it does , fairhead says that will be part of the public consultation .
the level of funding will clearly dictate what we can and ca n't do .
it 's for the public to help us decide where we should be making the investments and where we should pull back .
my colleague mark sweney has tweeted : mark sweney ( @ marksweney ) john whittingdale quips that new director of the bbc trust jon zeff - ex dcms - is `` poacher turned game keeper '' .
fairhead says bbc does impact on the market , but in a good way .
clearly if you have an organisation that is funded to the tune of â£ 3.5bn there will be some impact .
data will show the existence of the bbc has resulted in the creative and media environment in the uk being one that is looked at in the world as one of the exemplars of creative media .
labour mp steve rotheram now asking questions , quoting people who have said the bbc is doing too much .
what does the bbc need to do fewer , better , how does it distort the market ?
fairhead says audience wants quality programmes and balance .
there is one view you should only do programmes where there are n't commercial examples , that would be too far and absolutely not what the public want .

if you have a universal service , you have to get the balance right between appropriate levels of entertainment , popular programmes ¦ equally the bbc should be doing programmes that are always of good quality .
fairhead says trust 's research is high quality .
changing technology will allow more informed and richer information about what viewers think .

documents.title: liddiment : audience said bbc1 getting stale
text: liddiment , talking about the trust 's recent tv channels review , says it was clear we were getting a signal from the audience that bbc1 was getting a little bit stale ¦ and we responded to that .
tory mp angie bray , putting questions to david liddiment , bbc trustee .
debate currently around process of charter renewal audience involvement , timing , role of the trust etc is not what that charter should look like .
over to ben bradshaw , labour mp .
but by delaying until after the general election , voters wo n't know what they are voting for .
should n't political parties make clear their thoughts on the bbc in their manifestos ?
zeff says it 's up to them .
bradshaw says voters will go into election blind unless political parties make clear what their intentions towards the bbc are .
you might have a government in power that wants to abolish the bbc .
suggests it 's the trust 's role , defending the interests of the licence fee , to ask parties what their intentions are .
zeff says it 's not his , or the trust 's role .
crouch says other witnesses have expressed concern to the committee that charter renewal has n't started yet .
you 're just not worried ?
zeff : it 's not been delayed .
it is for the government to set the timetable and the process .
i do n't have concerns .
the important thing is that it is an open process .
iterative becoming a word of the day already .
one from zeff , one from fairhead .
if you 're not sure¦
tracey crouch , tory mp , asks if jon zeff is concerned charter renewal has n't started yet .
zeff says it 's not a problem , in the circumstances , it 's a welcome decision by the government to be clear it wo n't start the process until after the general election .
on finances and salaries , fairhead says she would still like to make sure there is real clarity in remuneration , to make sure everyone knows where the buck stops .
this was a real issue between her predecessor lord patten and ex-dg mark thompson over the notorious big payoffs to former execs .
fairhead says it 's only her second week in the job , but bigs up the economic benefits and skills training function of the bbc .
says she has also been struck by the quality of the programme and the dg 's focus on quality , creativity .
first reference to david attenborough .
his life story series brilliant .

on her first day in office , rona fairhead says she had a combined meeting with the executive team , executive board ( including tony hall ) and members of the trust to set the strategic context for the bbc for the future .

documents.title: and we 're off !
text: first up is committee chair and tory mp john whittingdale , doing the intros and putting the first question to rona fairhead - what 's the trust 's role ?
you can also watch live coverage of the committee at parliamentlive.tv or the bbc parliament channel .
it 's either running a little late or my watch is fast .
and here 's the 11 inquisitive men ( and women ) who make up the culture , media and sport select committee .
for those of you not familiar with jon zeff , he was appointed trust director in march this year , succeeding nicholas kroll .
he was previously a director at the department of culture , media and sport .

outgoing bbc trustee david liddiment is a former director of programmes at itv , among many other things , and was responsible for the trust 's recent tv channels review which was critical of bbc1 and posed serious questions about bbc3 's online offering ahead of the proposed closure of its digital tv channel .
expect plenty of debate about the licence fee and its potential decriminalisation after the culture secretary brought forward a review into the way we fund the bbc .
the bbc has said decriminalisation would cost it the best part of â£ 200m a year , the equivalent of bbc4 , cbbc and cbeebies .
in other words , decriminalise the licence fee and iggle piggle gets it .

documents.title: good morning
text: new bbc trust chairman rona fairhead will be making her first appearance before mps since she was confirmed in the job last month .

it will be a busy day for john whittingdale 's house of commons culture , media and sport select committee , who will also be taking evidence from fairhead 's fellow trustee , david liddiment , and the director of the bbc trust , jon zeff , almost as new in the job as fairhead .
as if that was n't enough , they will be followed by culture secretary sajid javid at midday .

the to the future of the bbc , the last session in the committee 's marathon inquiry into what the bbc could and should look like after the renewal of its royal charter at the end of 2016 , and how it will be funded .
the last time fairhead appeared before mps she was effectively in the final throes of applying for the trust job .
mps were largely impressed by what she had to say , unanimously backing her appointment .
the opening session , with fairhead , liddiment and zeff , is due to begin at 10.30am

Javid hints that he believes the royal charter should not be scrapped

1.00pm BST

Javid âconcernedâ about impact on indies of BBC proposal to spin-off production business

1.06pm BST

Javid says "fresh look" needed at how the BBC should be governed

12:34
Javid: âruling nothing outâ in BBC funding options

11.54am BST

bulletin.text: Trust chair and culture secretary give evidence to the Commons culture, media and sport committee.
